By the end of this module, participants will be able to:

Assimilate disaster elements specific to the Plan of Action Milestone to make staffing suggestions and simulate an initial POAM meeting with disaster leadership

Explain the importance of leadership adaptability and the five steps of the cognitive FORCE model
Compare and contrast different leadership styles and describe different aspects of your own leadership style

Assimilate disaster elements specific to the Plan of Action Milestone to make staffing suggestions and simulate an initial POAM meeting with disaster leadership

Describe the difference between Tier 1 and Tier 2 meetings and the STTL role in each type of meeting as well as articulate pertinent updates through simulated participation in Tier 1 Leadership meetin

Assimilate disaster elements such as Preliminary Damage Assessment (PDA), disaster leadership battle rhythm, and current and expected workload to make staffing recommendations

The FEMA PA Program provides assistance to State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial (SLTT) Governments, and certain types of Private Non-Profit (PNP) organizations so that communities can quickly respond
Key to the OSSP’s job is their support of the PA mission and leadership. As such, the OSSP is responsible for a basic understanding of the PA Program in order to effectively perform their part within

fields.competency: Leading and Working with Joint Teams
Planning, Managing and Conducting Joint Operations

fields.description: Provide reliable, culturally sensitive, responsive, and courteous service to stakeholders (i.e., active listening skills to include asking clarifying questions, courteous tone of voice)
Communicate with applicants, discuss current case status and ensure the applicant understands disaster assistance programs and the recovery process, providing referrals as appropriate
Demonstrate knowledge of current IA program guidelines and policies for the delivery of disaster assistance
Use common terminology (e.g., organizational functions, incident facilities, resource descriptions, position titles)
Follow procedures for handling sensitive information and safeguarding Personally Identifiable Information (PII)
Understand the activities involved in the delivery of mass care and emergency assistance
Review documentation provided by the applicant or scanned to NEMIS to verify information is complete and appropriate in order to advise the survivor of receipt and/or missing/incomplete information
Record contacts/comments in NEMIS ensuring entries are complete and concise

Identify federal, state, local, voluntary, faith-based, community organization, and private sector resource partners that can meet disaster-related needs through donations of volunteer time, cash or material goods
Make appropriate referrals to internal and external partners regarding survivor immediate or unmet needs
Successfully complete a registration for disaster assistance in accordance with the Registration Intake Users’ guide in any working environment
Access applicant files while following Identity Verification and Release of Information procedures and refer to said procedures prior to sharing information with a third party
Thoroughly review cases in NEMIS using Applicant Update and address case file issues including Data Changes

Report on voluntary agency resources, capabilities, and operations to FEMA personnel supporting the JFO and Branch Offices, such as Public Assistance (PA), Mass Care, Logistics (LOG), Other Federal Agencies (OFAs)
Assist with set up and coordination of referral mechanisms for maximum Individuals and Households Program (IHP) awards
Identify and report voluntary agency issues and concerns and voluntary agency or community disaster activities to immediate supervisor
Provide information regarding voluntary agency activities to relevant Joint Field Office (JFP) partners (i.e., Hazard Mitigation (HM), External Affairs (EA), et. al.)

Provide voluntary, faith-based, community organizations, and the private sector with information on the sequence of delivery, including FEMA disaster programs and pertinent information relevant to the community’s priorities
Relay guidance and educate voluntary organizations on IA programs, policies, and guidelines to improve unity of effort and survivor service delivery
Set up and maintain Voluntary Agency Liaison (VAL) records and files in accordance with Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) records management directives
Assemble Voluntary Agency Group (VAG) files for the transition to the Region in accordance with instructions from immediate supervisor

Assist with the development of a directory that provides information on the recovery resources of government agencies, voluntary organizations, foundations, and other organizations that can help address disaster-caused unmet needs
Utilize computer-based systems to effectively access survivor or disaster-specific operational information, such as Web Emergency Operations Center (WebEOC), NEMIS, et al.
Educate voluntary organizations on government mass care support efforts to improve service delivery and support shelter transition efforts
Attend and summarize findings from meetings with voluntary, faith-based, and community organizations outside the JFO for VAL team counterparts.

Provide technical assistance to the information and referral agencies in identifying disaster resources, communicating their service, and integrating with recovery partners (i.e., United Way, 2-1-1, et al.)

Serve as support staff and complete assignments for FEMA-led initiatives, such as Multi- Agency Shelter Transition Team (MASTT) teams, Disaster Case Management (DCM), FEMA Corps, Disaster Survivor Assistance (DSA), et al.
Support the state VAL in messaging for and engagement of spontaneous volunteers
Identify resources to address gaps in areas such as emergency debris, muck-out, and gutting operations (which may include voluntary and faith-based partners and/or Americorps Mission Assignments)
Facilitate referrals and information sharing regarding applicants with emergency and/or unmet needs
Conduct a transition meeting with voluntary agency partners and provide them with Regional contact information
Explain written consent process to voluntary agency partners to assist them in garnering information for individual applicant casework
Participate in multi-county or state-wide collaborative calls to address geographic coordination issues
Provide opportunities for OFA partners to share information with long-term recovery members through informal meetings, presentations, brochures, et al.

Provide technical assistance to voluntary organizations offering long-term recovery resources to disaster survivors by assisting with the identification of resources and supporting organizations to address their limiting factors and enhance collaboration
Recommend potential voluntary, faith-based, and community service providers as members or resource-providers for long-term recovery committees
Assist with the development and review of 'Day-in-the-Life-Of' (DILO) and 'Week-in-the-Life-Of' (WILO) summary for PDMGs and check alignment of staff activities with operational goals and priorities.
Develop 'Day-in-the-Life-Of' (DILO) and 'Week-in-the-Life-Of' (WILO) based on operational goals and priorities. Submit to and discuss with NPAGS.
Conduct daily huddle with PDMGs to provide operational goals and objectives; ensure PDMGs participate in huddles, reporting their activities and issues.

Regularly conduct Sit-Withs with PDMGs to discuss project development progress; provide constructive feedback, identify and provide coaching and mentoring where needed; Conduct weekly wrap up meeting with PDMGs to review progress.
Review eligibility issues flagged by PDMG or CRC staff and assess if a Determination Memo is required for ineligible facility, work, and/or cost.

Communicate to PDMGs the Recipient/EHP/Mitigation/Insurance/Recovery Support Function involvement in the project development process; verify PDMGs maintain the appropriate level of engagement and meet expectations.
Routinely spot check projects to ensure PDMGs correctly formulate projects,  accurately request documentation/information, and meet performance expectations for these activities.
Provide guidance to supervisors regarding the application of policies and directives (e.g. JFO Administrative Memo, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) policies and directives.
Utilizing Grants Manager, track progress of Damage Description and Dimensions approval and codification.
Utilizing Grants Manager, verify PDMG resolves Requests for Information in coordination with Applicant within performance expectations.
Utilizing Grants Manager, verify site inspections and/or validations are scheduled according to performance expectations.

Utilizing Grants Manager, verify the scheduling and completion of Exploratory Calls and Recovery Scoping Meetings; ensure PDMG meets performance expectations and achieves outcomes described in related job aids/tools, including detailed notes in Grants Manager.

Monitor project status in GM to assess when Applicants are ready for Recovery Transition Meetings; monitor Recovery Transition Meetings scheduling and completion to ensure PDMGs meet performance expectations.
Prepare PDMGs for Applicant assignment by ensuring they receive Disaster Overview Briefing; conduct initial sit-with to assess skill sets and determine additional support that may be needed.
Establish and monitor team milestones in alignment with strategic milestones established by field leadership.
Review PDA, Disaster Operating Profile, and other data to gain understanding of event impacts and declared area; brief staff.
Verify Damage Inventories have been signed by applicants, on day 61 utilizing Grants Manager.
Monitor projects in Phase 4 to verify PDMGs review projects within performance expectations.
Prepare PDMGs for Exploratory Call; attend at least one Exploratory Call and conduct Sit-With to discuss observations and provide additional support, as necessary.
Prepare PDMGs for Recovery Scoping Meeting; attend Recovery Scoping Meeting if additional support may be needed.

Verify PDMGs develop and update a Project Development Plan in coordination with each assigned Applicant, including regular follow-up meetings, target timelines for document collection, site inspections, project reviews. Ensure Project Development Plan information entered in Grants Manager.
Participate in Field/Consolidated Resource Center coordination calls.
Utilizing Grants Manager, verify PDMGs regularly update spend plan projections for each project
Meet with supervisor to keep them informed regarding progress, status, and changes.
Verify Site Inspector uploads all documents in accordance with the published naming convention to the system after PDMG concurs with DDD.
Inform supervisor and Unit, Division, or Group staff of decisions, changes, and incidents (e.g., milestone progress, resources allocation, and demobilization).
Recommend adjustments to strategy, timeframes, expectations, or resource allocation to staff and leadership.
Review work completed by teams for consistency with direction and tactical outcomes from JFO strategic plans (e.g. the Incident Action Plan, Integrated Operating Concept, management plans).
Establish regular communication with assigned supervisors to address operational issues and developments.
Spot check Site Inspectors DDDs, Site Inspection Reports, and supporting documentation. Verify for completion and that documents are uploaded identifying the correct Category of documentation.

Assess disaster profile (e.g. number of projects in the Standard Lane, types of damages, and geographic considerations) to develop a recommendation on number of Site Inspectors required for disaster operation and situational awareness.

Verify that SIs in crew completed entire work order cycle, including preparing for site inspections, performing assigned site inspections, and developing an accurate DDD supported with photos, sketches, and accurate calculations.
Track site inspection and validation work flow from receipt of Work Order to close out of Work Order.
Track progress and quality of site inspections and work order cycle and make adjustments as needed.
Create and explain the vision for tasks and work assignments and how they fit into the context of FEMA's mission, operation, and goals.
Evaluate requests for additional supplies, services, and equipment; provide recommendations to leadership for approval.
Review Site Inspection and Work Orders from the Standard Lane or DIU for accuracy.
Provide Site Inspectors with the requirements of their site inspection work and review assignment with staff.
Conduct weekly coordination meetings with Site Inspectors to review lessons learned and areas of improvement.
Maintain accountability and updated information in the Deployment Tracking System (DTS) and call down roster.
Conduct daily Huddles communicating operational goals and updates to staff.
Conduct initial briefing with incoming supervisors; discuss experience, leadership style, and operational needs; and provide situational information and direction on work assignments.
Gather data on training gaps across Unit, Division, or Group and collaborate with Training Unit to identify requirements and select training opportunities.

Solicit feedback from staff on how to improve efficiency and effectiveness of plans, processes, and procedures; based on staff input implement improvement actions within your area of responsibility and provide feedback to leadership.
Make travel arrangements and submit travel vouchers every 14 days.
Submit weekly or daily 'Day in the life of' (DILO) and 'Week in the life of' (WILO) summary to immediate field supervisor in chain of command upon completion.
Support supervisors in communicating performance deficiencies to staff (e.g. provide advice, participate in formal feedback sessions).
Assess the need for and monitor the use of overtime hours and administrative expenses at the Unit, Division, or Group level, avoiding unnecessary expenditures.
Meet with supervisor to keep them informed regarding progress, status, and changes.
Develop and maintain organizational chart for PA
Discuss eligibility issues with the Applicant and Recipient.
Utilize information included within the PA Daily Operations Report and Grants manager to provide progress reports on the PA program from delegate assigned.
Provide excellent customer service on-site inspection; clearly communicate what you are there to do and continue communicating with POC as inspection occurs.
Review disaster specific information relating to assigned Applicants.
Integrate Recipient, EHP, and MIT from the beginning into the PA operations.
Make accurate lane recommendations for project processing.
In accordance with the phased delivery sequence, set operational objectives to contribute to the planning process.
Use Grants Manager to meet reporting requirements and manage the event.
Communicate status of Work Orders to all stakeholders to promote and ensure transparency.

OSSP completes delegated tasks as assigned by OSTL/OSCL. | Coordinates with HR and follows HR procedures for staff deployment. | Addresses initial deployment needs (equipment, IT, HR).  | Monitors DTS deployer for incoming and outgoing staff.  | Tracks length of deployments and notate staff approaching 50 weeks.  | Provides summary reports regarding these metrics to OSTL/OSCL within a timeline specified by OSTL/OSCL.  | Completes delegated tasks with minimal or no feedback from OSTL/OSCL.
Coordinate with HR to ensure Public Assistance staff are assigned to appropriate WebTA supervisors.
Assist with the identification of training needs and training coordination.
Participate in huddles and Sit-Withs and complete 'Day in the life of (DILO)' and 'Week in the life of (WILO),' as directed by Operations Support Leadership.
Provide meeting support to Operations Support Task Force Leader and Public Assistance leadership.
Extract and analyze pertinent program information from a variety of sources in preparation of developing the Public Assistance portion of the Incident Action Plan/Incident Support Plan.
Coordinate with Logistics to determine available supplies and equipment, requests for spaces, and other logistical needs.
Develop Public Assistance internal reports and provide data as directed by Public Assistance leadership and as required by the Planning section.
Use information from DTS Deployer to generate call down roster. Develop and distribute a call down roster to senior leadership and staff.
Utilize DTS Deployer to collect and track responder information (i.e. deployment histories, staff availability, staff types, etc.) as requested by PA leadership.
Assist Operations Support Task Force Leader with coordinating and tracking deployments and responder data via DTS Deployer for Public Assistance staff.
Develop and maintain organizational chart for PA
Prepare overtime justifications as directed by Operations Support Task Force Leader.
Coordinate staff on-boarding and demobilization requirements with Logistics (APO & IT), Human Resources, and Security.
Track daily accountability of all PA staff to ensure safety.
Demonstrate knowledge of FEMA operations, procedures, resources, and organization
Work with the Finance Section to facilitate travel and human resources needs in the absence of Administration staff assigned to geographic branch or division.
Work with the Finance Section to facilitate travel and human resources needs in the absence of Administration staff assigned to geographic branch or division.

Support and assist with the preparation of five Situation Reports, five Common Operating Pictures (COP) and other Situation Unit products and tasks for five (5) operational periods (not to exceed 72 hours or less).
Demonstrate knowledge of Recovery Support Functions and resources.
Support and assist with the preparation of Situation Reports, Common Operating Pictures (COP) and other Situation Unit products and tasks for three (3) operational periods.
Engage Emergency Support Functions (ESF) and resources to address a specific program opportunity or challenge.
Manage resources; check-in, tracking, and status reporting.
Provide necessary information and support to participating SLTT and federal agencies.
Ensure local resource requests for support are routed properly through the state process.

Explain the difference between 404 and 406 hazard mitigation programs (as outlined in 44 Code of Federal Regulations, HM functional/program policy documents, HM guidance documents) and explain basic eligibility requirements to internal and external partners.
Follow up and provide feedback on the issues and concerns of supported or assigned SLTT officials and communicate these to the OSC.
Consult with FEMA Program Group/Division Supervisors and ESF Leads prior to making any organizational or tactical adjustments which may affect their program or function operations.

Participate in the coordination and discussion of Hazard Mitigation Proposal (HMP) strategies and preparation with HM 406 Specialist, PA Project Specialist and Environmental/Historic Preservation prior to development.
Identify and connect appropriate HM staff with internal and external partners to create relationships, answer questions, speak to Program regulations and FEMA policies, and resolve needs.
Verbalize understanding of and adherence to current IA program guidelines and policies regarding timelines, determination of eligibility, execution sequence and delivery of disaster assistance.
In coordination with JFO Direct Housing Group and state POC, discuss establishing the Direct Housing (DH) program, developing the DH strategy, timelines, and housing program options.
Spend at least 7 days with a FEMA VAL assigned to the disaster and be able to accurately describe VAL roles and responsibilities both at the JFO and field level.
Support the IA Branch (minimum 21 day detail) splitting time between DRC, field, and JFO.

Understand NEMIS role in Applicant registration, determination of eligibility, and other activities. In coordination with IA, discuss types of information entered and retained within NEMIS to identify and address case file issues including data changes and file updates.
Describe to internal and external stakeholders the components of Other Needs Assistance (ONA), its application at an incident, and importance to survivors.
Assist Public Assistance Site Inspector (minimum 7 day detail) with the preparation, conduct and product development of at least five site visits of at least two different Categories of Work.

Support Program Delivery Manager (minimum 21 day detail) by assisting with project development, site inspections, data/information gathering, and development of potential 406 Mitigation and HMGP opportunities.
Attend and observe one community (Town Hall) meeting that has a focus on flood insurance matters.
Attend at least one (1) State/Tribal/Territorial Hazard Mitigation Grant Program Applicants Briefing.
Detail to HM Community Education and Outreach for a minimum of 7 days; distribute and explain HM recovery and rebuilding information, including NFIP to disaster-affected communities.
Explain the Hazard Mitigation Grant Program project process and different mitigation methods and explain basic HMGP eligibility requirements with internal and external stakeholders.
Explain the purpose of the State Hazard Mitigation Plan and the disaster Hazard Mitigation Strategy, and the relationship between the two, to internal and external stakeholders.
Identify and connect appropriate HM staff with internal and external partners to create relationships, answer questions, speak to Program regulations and FEMA policies, and resolve needs.
Identify appropriate Subject Matter Expert (SME) to speak to hazards performance and analysis.
Implement Section 1206 of the Disaster Recovery Reform Act (DRRA) through the Public Assistance Program as it pertains to the NFIP.
Interpret flood maps and base flood elevations to support decision-making.
Observe at least one day of Substantial Damage inspections.
Observe more than one insurance agent visit.
Participate in at least three 406 project site visits, each for a different category of work and each using different mitigation technique.
Participate in the coordination of proposed NFIP strategies and objectives with FEMA/State NFIP Group supervisors prior to development.
Request policy and claim data during a disaster while following the privacy guidelines in releasing data.
Review and provide input to the long term substantially damaged process playbook.
Describe the IRC organization, resources, and operations to another FEMA component.
Review the process for responding to insurance related congressional inquiries.

Identify and develop potential 406 Mitigation and Hazard Mitigation Grant Program opportunities through discussions with Public Assistance staff, attendance of Exploratory Calls and Recovery Scoping Meetings, project site visits and review of Project Worksheets.
Maintain an accurate map of the completed areas of responsibility.
Detail for minimum of four (4) days as Disaster Survivor Assistance Task Force Leader trainee, successfully learning and demonstrating the DSA Task Force Leader Tasks.
Detail for minimum of seven (7) days as Disaster Survivor Assistance Specialist trainee, successfully learning and demonstrating tasks from the DSA Specialist PTB.
Detail for minimum of three (3) days as Disaster Survivor Assistance Crew Leader, successfully learning and demonstrating DSA Crew Leader Tasks.
Track resources in a designated geographic area and notify leadership of completion/changing mission requirements.
Identify and document local issues, objectives, and resource needs.Knowledge Application

Establish a task force to address a functional challenge, identify the resources needed (subject matter experts, support personnel, tools, equipment, etc.) and outline each member's roles and responsibilities.
Lead a task force in creating strategies, objectives, and tactics/tasks to achieve the required end state over the duration of the incident.
Lead a task force in developing timeline, metrics, and milestones to measure success of objectives, strategies, and/or tasks that meet the established end state.
Lead a task force in identifying and obtaining resources needed to carry out tactics and tasks (fill out RRFs, write contract scopes of work, develop MOUs, order through DTS, etc.)
Coordinate federal resources in the division segment to meet local objectives/needs, IAP objectives, and Division Supervisor's intent.
Establish and maintain contact with local officials.
Facilitate technical assistance and answers to local jurisdiction questions.
Track resources, ensure all activities are consistent with 204s, and relay changes to appropriate geographic and functional leadership and Resources Unit.
Relay local issues, objectives, and resource needs to the Division Supervisor.
Manage the development and distribution of planning and project management products for the division or geographic branch in accordance with Planning Section guidelines.
Collect, verify, and transmit incident information in a timely and accurate manner and submit to supervisor, situation unit lead, and other relevant stakeholders.
Monitor progress and provide updates to leadership; provide guidance and resources to task force members.

Support and assist with tracking resources, preparation of five Incident Action Plans, and development of other Resource Unit Products for five (5) operational periods (not to exceed 72 hours or less).
Support and assist with tracking resources, preparation of Incident Action Plans, and development of other Resource Unit Products for three (3) operational periods.
Lead or assist the assigned planners with the development of a written functional plan (e.g., current planning, future planning, or crisis action planning).
Certify Use of Operational Planning Worksheet (ICS 215) in WebEOC to develop tasks and identify resource assignments.
Collaborate with the state to support incident action planning process and synchronize division or geographic branch operations.
Assist the division supervisor and other division resources in the development of tactical plans.
Convert appropriate segments of the functional plan to operational planning worksheets (ICS 215).

fields.elo: Identify the importance of a Presidential Disaster Declaration for Individual Assistance (IA) programs
Identify Mass Care and Emergency Assistance (MC/EA) activities of Emergency Support Function (ESF) #6
Define the role of Individual Assistance (IA) programs
Describe the purpose of Registration Intake (RI)
Indicate ways to register for disaster assistance
Identify acceptable documentation from applicants trying to apply for assistance
Recognize the appeals process
List the FEMA core values
Explain the importance of cultural awareness
Identify Disabilities and other Access and Functional Needs (AFN)
Differentiate between verbal and non-verbal communication
Interpret the difference between external and internal communication barriers
Define active listening
Explain critical thinking
Define features and tools within the National Emergency Management Information System (NEMIS)
Describe the Applicant Inquiry (case review) process
Explain the Applicant Update process
List the updates authorized in the field
Demonstrate ability to access the FEMA Intranet
Perform steps to locate Individual Assistance (IA) Resources
Identify frequently used Individual Assistance (IA) Resources
Demonstrate proficiency in the skills needed to perform as an Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) in a Disaster Recovery Center (DRC)
Relate your experience as a Disaster Survivor and Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) in the activity
Identify the importance of a Presidential Disaster Declaration for Individual Assistance (IA) programs
Describe the Sequence of Delivery
Differentiate services provided by partner entities
Describe the types of physical facilities and their services
Review FEMA policies concerning privacy of information
Identify federal requirements for Individual Assistance (IA) programs

Identify unhealthy responses to stress
Identify healthy responses to stress
Provide self-care suggestions
Identify the importance of a presidential disaster declaration for IA programs
Define the role of IA programs
Identify federal requirements for IA programs
Assemble a functional directory in the approved format that addresses disaster-caused unmet needs
Report the initial response activities from voluntary agencies in support of Preliminary Damage Assessment (PDA) or early VAL priority-setting processes
Develop an organized system of VAL files for transition to the region
Use computer-based incident management systems to access operational information
Perform steps to locate IA Resources
Identify frequently used IA Resources
Describe the National Response Framework (NRF)

Recognize the four (4) main functions of ESF #6

Explain Sequence of Delivery
Update FEMA personnel on current voluntary agencies’ capabilities
Support information and referral agencies through technical assistance
Assist state with engagement of unaffiliated volunteers
Identify resources to address gaps in response and recovery initiatives
Complete assignments for FEMA-led initiatives
Document findings for Voluntary Agency Liaison (VAL) team counterparts
Make appropriate referrals for disaster survivors with unmet and emergency needs
Provide transition information to voluntary agency partners and regional long-term recovery groups
Provide technical assistance to voluntary organizations offering long-term recovery resources
Identify long-term recovery voluntary, faith-based, and community service resource providers for long-term recovery committees
Educate long-term recovery organizations on the mechanisms of federal information sharing including privacy act limitations
Explain the applicant written consent process to voluntary agency partners
Explain the difference between leadership and management
Compare and contrast different leadership styles and describe different aspects of your own leadership style
Explain how Emotional Intelligence can be used in the workplace
Explain the importance of leadership adaptability and the five steps of the cognitive FORCE model
Identify different learning styles and describe ways to effectively train employees
Identify different communication and interpersonal skills and demonstrate how to use them effectively as a Program Delivery Task Force Leader (PDTL)
Explain how to establish an effective team culture and foster teamwork
Demonstrate effective leadership strategies for time management, handling challenges, resolving conflict and difficult conversations
Identify effective leadership skills and how they relate to the role of Program Delivery Task Force Leader (PDTL)

Explain the role of a Program Delivery Task Force Leader (PDTL) in change and ways to manage change effectively
Identify key supervisory responsibilities of a Program Delivery Task Force Leader (PDTL)
Define Reasonable Accommodations and when to apply them
Discuss effective strategies for resolving conflicts

Describe the basic financial principles of being a supervisor at FEMA
Identify and describe key Program Delivery Task Force Leader (PDTL) roles and responsibilities to successfully lead, coach, mentor and evaluate staff

Identify when and describe how to establish and monitor team milestones through staff reports of activities and issues in Huddles and weekly wrap-up meetings

Create a dashboard with tiles and widgets in Grants Manager (GM) to verify Program Delivery Manager (PDMG) resolves Requests for Information (RFIs)

Create a dashboard with tiles and widgets in Grants Manager (GM) to verify the scheduling and completion of Exploratory Calls (ECs) and Recovery Scoping Meetings (RSMs)

Explain how to use a Preliminary Damage Assessment (PDA), Disaster Operating Profile (DOP) and Disaster Overview Briefing (DOB) to gain understanding of event impacts and declared areas to prepare team assignments

Evaluate and identify eligibility issues flagged by subordinate or Consolidated Resource Center (CRC) staff and determine whether a Determination Memo is needed for ineligible facility, work and/or cost

Describe how to routinely spot check projects in Phase 2 to ensure Program Delivery Managers (PDMGs) correctly formulate projects and accurately request documentation and/or information to ensure performance expectations are met

Describe how to verify that Program Delivery Managers (PDMGs) maintain the appropriate level of engagement with the Recipient, Environmental Historic Preservation (EHP), Mitigation, Insurance and Recovery Support Functions (RSFs) to ensure PDMGs meet expectations

Describe how to verify that Program Delivery Managers (PDMGs) update their Project Development Plans in coordination with each assigned Applicant and in alignment with strategic milestones established by field leadership

Describe the role of Program Delivery Managers (PDMGs) in regularly updating spend plan projections for each project and discuss how the Program Delivery Task Force Leader (PDTL) ensures any updates are performed before sending the project to Consolidated Resource Center (CRC)

Describe the process of monitoring projects in Phase 4 to verify Program Delivery Managers (PDMGs) review projects within performance expectations

Describe why valid Rework changes should be made expeditiously in Grants Manager and through transparent communication with our counterparts

Define the protocols for completing the Acknowledgement of Expectations, the supervisor-team member pairing, and explain when a Deployment Performance Evaluation (DPE) is mandatory
Define the role of an STTL in assisting with pairing team members with a Position Task Book Coach/Evaluator as applicable
Outline a communication strategy to gain and maintain situational awareness
Simulate conversations to meet and become familiarized with disaster leadership and other stakeholders
Assimilate disaster elements such as Preliminary Damage Assessment (PDA), disaster leadership battle rhythm, and current and expected workload to make staffing recommendations
Articulate pertinent updates through simulated participation in Tier 1 Leadership huddles
Assimilate disaster elements to gain situational awareness for scope of the disaster, types and quantities of damages and the geographical locations of the damages
Describe a process to gather disaster operational rules and procedures from the Operations Support Task Force Leader and apply them to a staffing and administrative needs assessment

fields.key_words: Plan of Action Milestone, POAM, leadership

fields.elo: Outline the purpose and protocol of attending Exploratory Calls (EC), Recovery Scoping Meetings (RSM) and follow up calls
Define the position of a manager in FEMA
Describe effective leadership skills and how they relate to the role of a manager
Describe the role of a manager and how it differs from the role of a supervisor
Describe how to represent FEMA in discussions, projects, or strategies that involve partners outside of one’s scope of supervision
Employ effective means of intelligence and information sharing and management
Describe how to establish a collaborative structure and process for government and nongovernmental entities at all levels
Implement effective strategies for developing and maintaining a positive work culture
Describe how to leverage Emotional Intelligence (EQ) in the workplace
Apply appropriate strategies to manage and reduce conflicts

Apply critical and creative thinking strategies to find effective solutions to issues
Demonstrate effective decision-making in order to implement strategies that align with organizational goals

Identify the three phases of crisis management
Document findings for Voluntary Agency Liaison (VAL) team counterparts

We are going to first look at how a change in roles impacts you personally. We are also going to look at how FEMA defines Supervision and what that means to your role. We will end by looking at a theory that shows how our focus changes as we advance in leadership roles.

Examine different Categories of Work for considerations and Red Flags to identify eligibility issues and assist Program Delivery Managers (PDMGs) with processing an Applicant’s project in an expeditious manner

Describe the difference between tasks and training for Operational and Programmatic knowledge and background, OPTL field performance; and Task Force Leader (TFL) and Management by Objectives (MBO) responsibilities
At the end of this module, participants will be able to:

Reference OPTL roles and responsibilities based on the OPTL Position Task Book (PTB), OPTL Position Description (PD), and Incident Management Handbook (IMH) and apply these to the personalized process and strategies for efficient position qualification and overall self-professional development

Apply knowledge of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Qualification System (FQS) process and Operations Task Force Leader (OPTL) Position Task Book (PTB) to draft an OPTL FQS Qualification Completion Plan
Describe the responsibilities of the Task Force and Strike (Resource) Team Leader at the Pre-Response, Response, Operational, Demobilization, and Post-Incident Phases of an incident

Describe and apply the relationships between the Threat and Hazard Identification and Risk Assessment (THIRA); Mission Areas and Core Capabilities; Lifelines, Lines of Effort (LOEs), and Functions; and Outcome-Driven Recovery (ODR)
Identify the relationship between Mission Areas and Core Capabilities; Lifelines, Lines of Effort (LOEs), and Functions; and Outcome-Driven Recovery (ODR)
Explain the difference between the Emergency Support Functions (ESF) and Recovery Support Functions (RSF)
Explain the impact of National Incident Management System (NIMS) on resources
Discuss relevant laws and other guidance to operational decisions, keeping in mind the spirit and intent of the law
Describe the intent of legal authorities that enable federal disaster response in Stafford Act incidents
Research disaster authorities to determine implications for State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial (SLTT) entities
Identify federal and potential other agency authorities
Identify aspects of Stafford Act incidents that fall under the authority of Other Federal Agencies (OFA)

Differentiate between Incident Management (IM) and Incident Support (IS)
Explain Non-Stafford Act responsibilities of the Operations (OPS) Section
Describe the Individual Assistance (IA), Public Assistance (PA) and Hazard Mitigation (HM) programs and explain how an Operations Task Force Leader (OPTL) interacts with program staff
Describe the organizational structure of the Unified Coordination Group (UCG) and Unified Coordination Staff (UCS)
Describe the basic roles, responsibilities, programs, resources, and capabilities of the different organizational elements in the Unified Coordination Group (UCG) and Unified Coordination Staff (UCS)
Describe the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) programmatic area responsibilities and methods, including Individual Assistance (IA), Public Assistance (PA), and Hazard Mitigation (HM)
Describe the FEMA Operational areas, including functional, geographic, Air Operations, Mission Assignment (MA) and Disaster Survivor Assistance (DSA)
Define the federal data sharing approach
Understand how to implement equity from an Operations Task Force Leader (OPTL) perspective
Describe the function and components of the Incident Management Organization (MBO) and Team and the Operations (OPS) Section ​
Describe the organizational structure of operations, including geographic, functional, and combined, as they relate to the different phases of disasters (Response, Recovery, and Long-Term Recovery)​
Explain the difference between Operational and Tactical Task Forces
Describe how to effectively, establish, lead, operate, and manage a tactical task force
Demonstrate all the steps in the Management by Objectives Process
Describe the steps of the analytical problem-solving model, and identify attributes associated with an effective decision-maker
Describe potential OPTL duties that may be assigned by a DIVS or Geographic Branch Director
Give examples of ways to overcome different challenges OPTLs may encounter

Identify and summarize the hard and soft skills needed for a unique role
Apply problem solving skills to challenges of an assigned unique role
Identify potential roles an Operations Task Force Leader (OPTL) may fulfill as a Force Multiplier
Identify additional training or information an Operations Task Force Leader (OPTL) would need to fulfill an assigned Force Multiplier role
Review previous course modules
Complete a post-assessment on course modules

Simulate establishing a task force to address a functional challenge, identify the resources needed (subject matter experts, support personnel, tools, equipment, etc.) and outline each member's roles and responsibilities
Establish/analyze and maintain Situational Awareness (SA)
Create a problem frame/problem statement
Create objectives, strategies and tactics to achieve the required end state over the duration of the incident

Identify and obtain resources needed to carry out tactics and tasks (fill out Resource Request Forms (RRFs), write contract scopes of work, develop Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs,) order through the Deployment Tracking System (DTS), etc.)
Develop a timeline, metrics and milestones to measure success of objectives, strategies and/or tasks that meet the established end state
Develop operational planning worksheets (Incident Command System (ICS) 215) based on provided information
Demonstrate delivering written and oral briefs including status reports
Discuss what the next steps are in the progression past an Operations Task Force Lead (OPTL) and understand what resources are available to them in their career progression

fields.tlo: At the end of this module, the Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) will be able to determine the types of assistance, the Sequence of Delivery for Individual Assistance (IA) programs, and the role of Emergency Support Functions (ESFs).

At the end of this module, the Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) will be able to complete a registration for a survivor seeking disaster assistance, in accordance with the Disaster Assistance Center (DAC) Call Center Registration Intake (RI) Users’ Guide.
At the end of this module, the Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) will be able to describe techniques for effectively communicating with disaster survivors.

At the end of this module, the Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) will be able to use the National Emergency Management Information System (NEMIS) to complete the Applicant Inquiry and Applicant Update processes.
At the end of this module, the Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) will be able to use Individual Assistance (IA) Resources to enter and/or update applicant information.
At the end of this module, the Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) will be able to simulate fulfilling their role in a Disaster Recovery Center (DRC).
At the end of this module, the Applicant Services Program Specialist (ASSP) will be able to describe effective methods for reducing and managing stress.
At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to determine the types of assistance and the Sequence of Delivery for Individual Assistance (IA) programs.

At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to use information management systems to access, establish, and maintain Voluntary Agency Liaison (VAL)-related records and access Individual Assistance (IA) Resources via the Intranet.

At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to interpret how the four main functions of Emergency Support Function (ESF) #6 coordinate the delivery of services when state, local, tribal, and territorial (SLTT) response and recovery needs exceed their capabilities.

At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to complete a registration, for a survivor seeking disaster assistance, in accordance with the Disaster Assistance Center (DAC) Call Center Registration Intake (RI) Users’ Guide and use the National Emergency Management Information System (NEMIS) to complete the Applicant Inquiry and Applicant Update processes.
At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to describe techniques for effectively communicating with disaster survivors.

At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to leverage strategic partnerships to provide support for various situational needs by developing a list of social service resources, identifying potential organizations to address needs, creating a briefing, and summarizing meeting discussions, including follow-up action items.
At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to identify and educate voluntary organization resource partners about unmet disaster-related needs.
At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to support long-term recovery groups by providing coordination and transition assistance.
At the end of this module, the Voluntary Agency Liaison Specialist (VASP) will be able to describe effective methods for reducing and managing stress.

By the end of this module, the participants will be able to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of leadership and management principles (e.g., emotion management, communication skills, interpersonal skills) crucial to the role of a supervisor within FEMA and explain how to apply those skills to various work situations.

By end of Module 2, the participants will be able to define the role of “supervisor” within FEMA and describe how roles, responsibilities and required skills change when moving from employee to supervisor.
By the end of this module, the participants will be able to effectively identify and describe the key roles and responsibilities of a Program Delivery Task Force Leader (PDTL).

By the end of this module, the participants will be able to effectively review and discuss Categories of Work and provide comprehensive guidance and assistance to Program Delivery Managers (PDMGs) in working with Applicants throughout the FEMA disaster recovery process.

By the end of this module, the participants will be able to recall procurement rules, identify potential risk areas, and utilize available tools and resources to ensure effective guidance and support to PDMGs in managing procurement processes within the FEMA disaster recovery framework.

By the end of this module, the participants will be able to develop a customized dashboard in Grants Manager (GM) with tiles and widgets to ensure comprehensive oversight and management of the disaster recovery.

By the end of this module, the participants will be able ensure successful management and oversight of Phases 3-5 within the FEMA disaster recovery process and the Public Assistance (PA) National Workflow.

By the end of this module, the participants will be able to effectively lead their team and demonstrate ways to assist the Public Assistance Group Supervisor (NPAGS) with delivery efforts for Phase 1.
By the end of module 7, Site Inspector Task Force Leaders (STTLs) will be able to review, research, and execute their role in phases 3-5 of the disaster for Work Order inquiries and rework requests.

By the end of Module 6, Site Inspection Task Force Leaders (STTLs) will understand how to navigate all phases of the site inspection Work Order (WO) process. This includes preparing for, assigning, monitoring and checking WOs for correct capture and validation of the Applicant damage claim by FEMA Public Assistance (PA) standards
By the end of Module 5, a Site Inspector Task Force Leader (STTL) will be able to effectively manage and accurately report on site inspection workflow, challenges and impacts.

By the end of Module 4, Site Inspector Task Force Leaders (STTLs) will be prepared to direct staff by effectively communicating with applicable disaster stakeholders toward accurate delivery of site inspection work orders utilizing FEMA technology.

By the end of Module 3, STTLs will be able to efficiently welcome the team to the disaster, communicate expectations, assess the skills of each team member and manage the “care and feeding “of the site inspection team during the life cycle of the disaster.

By the end of Module 2, Site Inspector Task Force Leaders (STTLs) will be able to assess the scope of the disaster, meet disaster leadership to determine the unified objectives and help coordinate and prepare for staffing and executing site inspections.
At the end of this module, FEMA managers will be able to describe the overall functions of a manager and identify the necessary skills to provide effective leadership.

The Terminal Learning Objective (TLO) for this module is that FEMA managers will be able to collaborate with other agencies to positively impact change, develop partnerships and demonstrate an understanding of managing relationships with external agencies in disaster and steady states.
At the end of this module, managers will be able to use common leadership theories to identify and develop good leadership practices at the personal, team, and public levels.
At the end of this module, the manager will be able to effectively communicate and support the development of subordinate supervisors.

At the end of this module, managers will be able to identify and demonstrate effective ways to complete managerial responsibilities, including those related to employment law, employee rights, labor relations, information dispute prevention, management and resolution, leveraging diversity and creating an inclusive work environment.

At the end of this module, FEMA managers will be able to explain operational management tasks, including staffing needs, the organization’s financial processes and procedures, and the technological needs of a functional team and organization.
At the end of this module, managers will be able to explain the role of a manager in incident management and demonstrate crisis and incident management skills.

At the end of this module, FEMA managers will be able to employ critical and creative thinking skills to find the most effective solutions to issues, demonstrate effective decision-making, and implement intentional strategies that align with organizational goals, assessing and managing risks and providing guidance on operational objectives.

At the end of this module, participants will be able to recall the FEMA Qualification System (FQS) objectives and its Position Task Book (PTB) requirements, important internal SharePoint sites, how to setup computer equipment, and identify Deployment Tracking System (DTS) Responder and the FEMA platform, FEMA's Mission Statement and Core Values, and Mandatory Training.

At the end of this module, participants will be able to distinguish FEMA Public Assistance (PA) employee staffing types, employee field roles, PA organizational charts, internal and external stakeholders, and describe the makeup of a Joint Field Office (JFO) and its organizational structure.

At the end of this module, participants will be able to recognize Lean Management principles and tools, and apply them to Huddles, Sit-Withs, Day in the Life Of (DILO) and Week in the Life Of (WILO) status updates.
At the end of this module, participants will be able to describe the National Workflow, the requirements of each phase and describe the Applicant's Declaration Process.

At the end of this module, participants will be able to identify Public Assistance Policy, eligibility concepts, categories of work and Damage Description and Dimensions (DDDs), to ensure adherence to laws and regulations when providing assistance to the Applicant.
At the end of this module, participants will be able to explain Public Assistance Applicant-Centric Recovery Options, Mitigation Opportunities and Compliance Requirements

At the end of this module, participants will be able to interpret Public Assistance (PA) processing tools, employ the Grants Manager (GM) and Grants Portal (GP) systems and identify the requirements for login access to Grants Manager (GM).
At the end of this module, participants will be able to interpret the expectations of basic communication and writing skills for all Public Assistance (PA) positions.​

By the end of Module 1, participants will be able to explain the phases of the Public Assistance (PA) National Workflow and describe the responsibilities of the Operations Support Specialist (OSSP) in supporting the PA program.

By the end of Module 2, participants will be able to describe the roles and responsibilities of the Operations Support Specialist (OSSP) in supporting the development of Incident Action Plan (IAP), Executive Summary (ExSum) and Situation Report (SitRep), describe the features of Crisis Management System (CMS) and identify Public Assistance (PA) milestones.

By the end of Module 3, participants will be able to recognize Lean Management principles and tools, and put them into practice by participating in Huddles and Sit-Withs, and completing Day in the Life Of (DILO) and Week in the Life Of (WILO).

By the end of Module 4, participants will be able to recall how the Operations Support Specialist (OSSP) gathers information from the Consolidated Resource Center (CRC) to support the Public Assistance (PA) National Workflow.
By the end of Module 5, participants will be able to reproduce Grants Manager (GM) navigation and Dashboards.

By the end of Module 6, participants will be able to locate Deployment Tracking System (DTS) features necessary for a successful Operations Support Specialist (OSSP), and duplicate Public Assistance (PA) Organizational Charts (OrgCharts).

By the end of Module 7, participants will be able to recall the role of the Operations Support Specialist (OSSP) in the onboarding and demobilization processes, accurately maintain records, and utilize contact groups to distribute information.
By the end of Module 8, participants will be able to locate and interpret Spend Plan (SP) reports.
At the end of this module, participants will be able to identify the roles and responsibilities of the Operations (OPS) Task Force Leader (OPTL).

At the end of this module, the Operations (OPS) Task Force Leader (OPTL) will understand the interdependent components and principles of Emergency Management (EM) that drive considerations for operational requirements of the incident.

At the end of this module, the Operations (OPS) Task Force Leader (OPTL) will be able to reference the laws and legal authorities that guide Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) operational decisions, as well as their application and potential conflicts between authorities.

At the end of this module, the Operations (OPS) Task Force Leader (OPTL) will be able to explain the Unified Coordination Group (UCG) and Unified Coordination Staff (UCS) organization structures, capabilities, roles, and responsibilities, from preparedness through response, recovery, and mitigation, including the three (3) Stafford Act Programs and Non-Stafford Act operational concepts.

At the end of this module, the Operations (OPS) Task Force Leader (OPTL) will understand and demonstrate how to establish, lead, operate and implement needed corrective actions and evaluate an Incident Task Force.
At the end of this module, participants will be able to demonstrate how to support Division Supervisors (DIVS) and Geographic Branch Directors (GEOBDs).​
At the end of this module, participants will be able to demonstrate how an Operations Task Force Leader (OPTL) fulfills an assigned unique role.

At the end of this module, participants will be able to explain the potential roles, additional training, and information an Operations Task Force Leader (OPTL) would need to fulfill an assigned Force Multiplier role.
By the end of this module, participants will have reviewed the course content and completed a post-assessment.
At the end of this module, participants will create a Task Force product for each step in the Management by Objectives (MBO) process.
Close out the course and describe what the next steps are in the progression of an Operations Task Force Lead.
